What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze popular music using history, media and cultural studies, and musicology. We discussed everything from Irish boy bands to Eurovision, Guinness, Irish pubs, Enya, country music, and Irish-American history. Through the lens of Irish music, we were able to analyze race, gender, nationalism, migration, international relations, the music industry, and diaspora. Going forward, I'll be better equipped to approach new music topics from an academic lens.
eurovision, fiddle riffs, jedward, pub decor in japan, literally everything?? best course ever?

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The organization of this class made it such a high point of my semester. The professors did an amazing job immersing us in a deep dive of Irish popular music, taking an unfamiliar topic and breaking it down using musicological concepts. We got to do interactive work, like an ethnography, a fiddle workshop with a local musician, and a Zoom call with one of the authors we read. Most of us came from a non-music major background, but the professors engaged us on topics like architecture and history that were familiar to us.
Aine and Professor Wright are incredible. Patient but also super insightful -- awesome course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course was so fantastic. We had some of the best discussions I've ever had in a classroom.

I would recommend this course, or any course taught by these instructors, to any student who wants a fun, interesting, and approachable environment to learn about music. For non-music people, this is an accessible way to start learning about musicology. For people with a musical background, I also recommend this course because it's an interesting and new subject, and popular music studies is underrepresented in academic musicology.
